JOHORE RIVER SCHEME
(Completion date)


    1. Mr A. P. Rajah asked the Prime Minister when the Johore River Scheme

Column: 4

will be completed to meet the additional water supplies required for Singapore.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply.

    The Johore River Scheme will take about four years to complete. On completion, it will be able to supply Singapore with an additional 25 million gallons of water a day.

    This Scheme is expected to ensure an adequate water supply for the island's population over a period of five to ten years. Should the consumption increase beyond what is expected at present, the Scheme would be extended. The minimum yield from the Johore River is approximately 300 million gallons a day.

    In the foreseeable future Singapore's consumption of water cannot exceed the potential supply from the Johore River.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, am I to understand that the first supply from the Johore River cannot be expected in Singapore before four years?

    Mr Chan Sun Wing: The answer is yes.

CITY COUNCIL BUDGET FOR 1960


    3. Mr A. P. Rajah asked the Prime Minister what steps have been taken in the exercise of the functions, duties, powers, discretions and authorities previously had and exercised by the City Council under the provisions of sections 71 and 72 of the Local Government Ordinance, 1957, with regard to the City Council Budget for 1960.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply. The Prime Minister received the City Council Draft 1960 Budget prepared in accordance with section 71 (1) of the Local Government Ordinance, 1957, on 23rd October 1959.

    The Prime Minister approved the Budget on 23rd December, in the exercise of his powers under section 72 (2) , subject to the deletion of development items and to further scrutiny of the Budget to effect economies.

    The draft Budget, as presented to the Prime Minister, provided for an estimated deficit of some $13 million. The Government has resolutely opposed deficit budgetting, and has made known its intention to effect all possible economies in public expenditure. The Prime Minister therefore gave instructions for a further scrutiny of special expenditure items, particularly those items which provide for projects which come within the scope of the Schedule to the Development Fund Ordinance, 1960. The work of scrutiny and deletion has been carried out by the Ministry of Finance in conjunction with the City Council and is still proceeding.

Column: 6



    While scrutiny is in progress, expenditure on items of special expenditure has been frozen, except where commitments have already been made prior to 1st January, 1960. When scrutiny has been completed, the Government will consider providing the funds necessary to implement those projects, which have been accepted. Any further deletions could be effected by Supplemental Budgets.

    A summary of the City Council 1960 Budget was published in the Gazette on 8th January, 1960.

Meanwhile, in accordance with the Statement, which appears in the P.A.P.'s Five-Year Plan - I refer to paragraph 7 of the Article "Unified Administration" in The Tasks Ahead, Part I - the City Council staff have been assured that they "need have no fear that they will lose their jobs or suffer any reduction in their salaries or existing Provident Fund benefits."

MOTOR VEHICLES
(THIRD-PARTY RISKS AND COMPENSATION) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.04 p.m.

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill re-enacts the provisions of Part II of the Road Traffic Ordinance, with the significant modification that all payments of compensation by insurers

Column: 17

in respect of third party risks are required to be paid to the Public Trustee as trustee for the persons entitled thereto, and that solicitation in respect of claims for such compensation is prohibited.

    Clause 4 of the Bill provides that, when any payment is made by way of compensation by an approved insurer or by the owner of a motor vehicle in respect of the death of or bodily injury to any person arising from the use of a motor vehicle on a road, such payment shall be made to the Public Trustee as trustee for the persons entitled thereto. The moneys received by the Public Trustee will be distributed to the persons entitled thereto after payment of costs and fees.

    Power is given to the Public Trustee to require .the approval of the court for a payment by way of settlement, where he considers the payment to be inadequate.

    Clause 7 of the Bill similarly requires that where any payment is made by an insurer under a judgment of the court, such payment shall be made to the Public Trustee as trustee for the persons entitled thereto.

    Clause 16 of the Bill makes it an offence for a person to solicit instructions or authority to act on behalf of any other person in respect of the making or commencement of any claim or action for damages for death or personal injury arising out of the use of a motor vehicle, or in respect of the negotiation, compromise or settlement of such claim or action. It is also made an offence for any person, other than a public officer or an advocate and solicitor, to make or cause to be made any claim on behalf of any other person for such damages. A public officer or advocate and solicitor who acts for another person in respect of such claim will only be entitled to payment of his taxed costs, and if any other sum is paid for work done or services rendered in respect of any claim or action for such damages, such sum may be recovered by the person who paid it

Column: 18



    The aim of the Bill is to put an end to the practice which is resorted to by some lawyers of engaging touts to solicit and obtain accident claims cases and arranging to keep a substantial portion of the compensation received for themselves. In this way the unfortunate victims of road accidents have been cheated of the sums rightly due to them by these unscrupulous lawyers, and I am glad to say that the majority of the members of the Bar and the insurance companies have welcomed the move of the Government to put a stop to this racket.

    Since the Bill has been introduced, a number of discussions have been held with the representatives of the Motor Insurance Association of Malaya and Borneo, and as a result of these discussions, a number of amendments have been agreed to, and I will seek to move these amendments in the Committee stage of this Bill. The most important of these amendments is to make it unnecessary for payments under $500 made by way of settlement to be paid to the Public Trustee.

    The opportunity has also been taken to incorporate in the amendments to be proposed a number of provisions from the Federation of Malaya's recent Road Traffic Ordinance.

    Sir, I beg to move.
